importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, marks a tragic incident involving a prominent songwriter, raising concerns about aviation safety and pilot communication protocols.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 18 to October 20, 2025, includes the incident and the release of the NTSB preliminary report, highlighting the timeline of events and the public response.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, was piloting a single-engine Cirrus SR22T plane when it crashed on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, killing all three people on board.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during its descent, and there were no mechanical failures found in the wreckage.

James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control; however, he failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), and the controller attempted to communicate with him but received no further response.
James had previously worked with major music artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and co-wrote Kenny Chesney’s 'Out Last Night', establishing his prominence in the music industry.
The incident underscores critical gaps in pilot communication and air traffic coordination, raising broader questions about aviation safety protocols and pilot training.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Grammy-winning songwriter and music industry collaborator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brett James is the central figure in the incident, as he was the pilot of the plane that crashed, and his prominence in the music industry brings significant public attention to the event.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB conducted the preliminary investigation into the crash and provided the official report, making it essential to understanding the cause and contributing factors.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Radio frequency used by pilots to share location when no air traffic control is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Failure to use CTAF contributed to the loss of communication and is a key factor in the investigation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his work with major music artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, when his Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' during a flight to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board's preliminary report found no mechanical failures, but identified a critical communication failure: James did not tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF) despite being instructed to do so, and failed to respond to air traffic control after announcing a 360-degree turn at 6,800 feet. This incident raises concerns about pilot communication protocols and aviation safety in visual approaches, particularly in remote or low-traffic areas.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters a ‘tightening spiral’ before crashing, NTSB says
